newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan army chief vows answer to India missiles.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan army chief vows answer to India missiles.

text.p: Army chief General Jehangir Karamat said on Wednesday that Pakistan must develop an "indigenous capability" to meet a perceived missile threat from neighbouring arch-rival India.
The general, quoted by the official APP news, made the statement in a speech at the Naval War College in Lahore, capital of Punjab province.
He was referring to a U.S. newspaper report that India had moved some of its medium-range Prithvi missiles to a prospective launch site near the border.
APP quoted Karamat as saying "in the absence of reassurances, we would have no option but to go ahead with the development of our indigenous capability".

He said the missile deployment and a recent alleged violation of Pakistan's airspace by an Indian aircraft seemed to be "deliberate policy decisions and would inevitably influence our response and the overall efforts for peace".

Pakistan voiced serious concern on Tuesday on the alleged deployment, reported by the Washington Post in Tuesday's editions, and said the move could trigger "a dangerous ballistic arms race" in South Asia.
The United States on Tuesday declared itself in "outright opposition" to the deployment of ballistic missiles by India and Pakistan, and said it was working to prevent such a move.
U.S. State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns, speaking at a news briefing in Washington, refused to confirm that India had moved such weapons to a prospective launch site.
The Washington Post report said U.S. intelligence agencies had concluded that less than a dozen missiles were now located near the city of Jullundur in the state of Punjab in northwest India.
Karamat said Pakistan's army had developed indigenous capabilities to ensure operational readiness and would "restructure to maintain effectiveness" without increasing defence expenditure.
"Our assertive defence in Siachen and on the line of control (in Kashmir) is a manifestation of this resolve," he said.

He was referring to several years of confrontation between the two sides on the disputed 20,000-foot (6,100-metre) high Siachen glacier, the world's highest battlefield, and the military control line dividing the disputed Himalayan region of Kashmir.
The Prithvi missiles currently are capable of carrying conventional but not nuclear warheads.

There have been repeated reports that Pakistan obtained M-11 missiles from China, which Islamabad denies, but Burns said Washington still had not decided that actual deployment of the Indian missiles had taken place.
Pakistan and India have fought three wars since their independence from Britain in 1947, two of them over Kashmir.
